text: Family Member: What’s that going to involve? Patient: What’s going to happen in six weeks? Doctor: Nothing. I just want to make sure your PSA isn’t like skyrocketing. (Door sound) Patient: Oh. Doctor: You know? Ten, ten is okay. Patient: Oh, ten isn’t climbing? Doctor: Yeah. Like, but if you’re fifty. That’s not in line with what I think is happening. You should level off with this stuff. Patient: Um hum. Family Member: It should come back down to like a seven or eight or whatever? Doctor: Yeah. Or even if it stays ten forever. I don’t care. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: But I don’t want it to go to a hundred because then I’d feel like, uh-oh, maybe somethings going on.

text: Patient: Right. Doctor: That’s not a whole lot, uh, for change. And your scans have not shown any major change. Patient: Right. Doctor: You know? The ones she did in, uh, end of November or December, whenever you saw her last. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: So, so based on that, I wouldn’t change anything. I think you should stick with, uh, the Lupron should be continued and the bone medication. Are they doing both of those? Family Member: Yeah. Today he gets- he gets his next Lupron February twelfth. Doctor: Okay. And what about the (Xgeva) Family Member: Uh-uh. Doctor: That may be helpful. So I’ll, uh, send a note to her. There is a bone-strengthening medication. Family Member: He’s seen a, uh, do you need to see your dentist before you-? Doctor: Yeah. Yeah. That kind of stuff. But, uh, but it can be very helpful, especially because the hormone therapy all this time has, can weaken the bones. So, so this may be something that will help, uh, and sometimes it can help with the bone pain, too, uh. You know? So I think all around it’s a good idea to get that started.

text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: I’m not gonna fuss. I’m gonna fast forward to say well, whatever that shows I think the question is, you know, what are my options. So, here’s where I’m at. If it’s more than bone, meaning, oh, shoot, maybe that thingy in the liver and the lymph nodes and all that is actually there again and that other one was sort of a fake out then I think you need chemo and I think we’ve been stalling enough for a while that the inevitable is about to happen Mr. H____ you just, you’re gonna, we’re just gonna have to do it Patient: Okay. Doctor: and that’s with docetaxel and Taxotere is the name of the chemo and we do have studies with that so I just, you know, I always want to make sure we talk about that. So, you’d get on Taxotere just alone once every three weeks. It’s an hour infusion. Standard of care anywhere you go in the US. Patient: Okay. Doctor: and then our studies are Taxotere plus high-dose vitamin C versus just the Taxotere. So, two-thirds of the people will get vitamin C. The other one third will just get the chemo. So, everybody gets chemo no matter how I swing this Family Member: everyone gets chemo. Which is great for me, you’re like wow, I guess it’s great for you but you know we all have mixed feelings a little bit. I get that. Patient: Right. Doctor: The second study is chemotherapy plus an immunotherapy versus chemotherapy. So, docetaxel plus immunotherapy versus docetaxel. So, you know, either one of those is doable. Again, if you had stuff outside of bone that’s probably what we should do. Hi, oh, for the opioids, Okay, for your pain, yeah. So, then the other part is what if you’re just bone. So, let’s say we do this and you’re just in your bones, no lymph nodes, liver, nothing, it’s clean then I think we should consider radium or Xofigo. Family Member: Together with the docetaxel? Doctor: No, just radium. So, there it’s um to combine with anything else is not standard of care and we don’t have our trial up yet with radium plus something. But, at this moment standard of care is just monthly radium for six months and that improves your survival span. So does chemotherapy but radium you can only give if it’s just in bone. So, if you have it like in the liver or whatever kind of like when we first started Patient: Um hum.

text: Patient: Um hum. Doctor: But it makes them susceptible when we go back down again. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So it’s sort of like not quite a selling point. Doctor: But the potential could be a bonus. I’m hopeful that today your testosterone will come, will be lower. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And your PSA will also be lower. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Because part of the PSA going up with the testosterone was just turning on the production number. Patient: Of the testosterone? Doctor: Even if it didn’t make the cancer grow, or, or the cancer grew, whatever, just turning off the, the hormone might turn off the production. So, um, usually I see the PSA drop back down some. Patient: Okay.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
